question: Does monocyte-derived IL-10 suppress CD4+ T cell activation and function? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: Triggering of PD-1 expressed on monocytes by PD-L1 expressed on various cell types induced IL-10 production and led to reversible CD4+ T cell dysfunction.
content.source_2: In primary co-cultures from healthy donors, microbial ligands that increased PD-1 levels and elicited IL-10 secretion by monocytes did not impair CD4+ T cell expansion or cytokine production; proliferation and IFN-Î³ release were comparable to unstimulated controls.
content.source_3: Microbial stimulation curtailed CD4+ T cell expansion and effector function by upregulating PD-1 on monocytes; subsequent PD-L1 engagement drove monocyte-derived IL-10 that mediated the suppression.
content.source_4: Ligation of PD-1 on monocytes by PD-L1 consistently reduced IL-10 release and was associated with augmented CD4+ T cell activation, indicating that monocyte IL-10 is not a mediator of T cell inhibition in this setting.
